Award.AwardTitle: Predicting Major Dry Spells of the Monsoon a Week to Ten Days in Advance
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to improve the understanding and prediction of dynamical mechanisms responsible for the formation and maintenance of dry spells of the Indian Summer Monsoon. The investigators will develop means to forecast dry spells of the Indian Summer Monsoon more accurately, on time scales of the order a few weeks, by utilizing a suite of multimodels and the superensemble strategy. This research includes (i) an analysis and calibration of TIGGE (Observing System Research and Predictability Experiment (THORPEX) Interactive Grand Global Ensemble) models; (ii) review of algorithms for downscaling and ensemble methodology; (iii) construction of TIGGE model forecasts and (iv) verification of a scenario of antecedents for the dry spells of the Indian Summer Monsoon.

The investigators have examined antecedents of the dry spells that include an eastward extension of the rain belt from west Africa (and the eastern Atlantic Intertropical Convergence Zone). The rains over near equatorial north Africa contribute to a stronger than normal local Hadley Cell, generation of supergradient winds along the westerly subtropical jet of the southern Mediterranean, dynamical conversions of anticyclonic shear vorticity into curvature vorticity. That results in the generation of a deep tropospheric blocking high that spans over the upper half of the troposphere. This high carries a descending lobe of very dry desert air that makes its way to central India during these dry spells. These will be the modeling components of this project.

With the large population and agricultural demands on water, the prediction of the dry spells of the monsoon a week to ten days in advance can be of immense socio-economic benefits. In terms of broader impacts, this project has a potential to demonstrate such a capability from a combination of diverse observational and modeling components. It can lead to similar thrusts for other parts of the monsoon world that are affected by similar intraseasonal variability. In addition, this project will train and support one graduate student and one post-doc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two important questions are always asked in the monsoon community i) When will there be a next dry spell within the Indian monsoon season? and ii) How long will that dry spell last?

These questions have a relevance to the issues of agriculture, water resources and the normal functioning of government. This relies on basic forecast information that the global weather services community provides for local regions. Real-time multimodels from the European Center (ECMWF), the U.S. National Weather Service (GFS), the U.K. Meteorological Office (UKMO), the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA), the Canadian Weather Service (RPN), the Australian Weather Model (BMRC), the U.S. Navy (NOGAPS), and the India Meteorological Departments (NCMRWF) model, plus a host of others provide useful information on the occurrence and duration of such dry spells. The collective wisdom of all such products can be combined into a consensus forecast. That is being done by my research group at Florida State University using a method, that was largely funded by NSF, called the multimodel superensemble (MMSE). This approach invokes a training phase and a forecast phase for the construction of the superensemble forecast. Invariably that forecast from the MMSE has been shown to be superior to that of the best model. The training phase relies on the past performance of models in these areas of forecast. That training phase provides useful information on the systematic errors of the member models. That appears as statistical weights. The result is that the superensemble method utilizes as many as 10 million such weights for the weather forecast problem. That large number comes from looking at a host of models, variables, and geographic locations through the entire depth of the atmosphere. As a result the large number of weights makes it possible to look at model errors arising from the model representation of physical processes. These are handled a bit differently by each model and these lead to systematic errors. This error removal by the MMSE is important for improved ensemble forecasts.

When our procedure is applied to monsoon datasets, the statistical information of the training phase provides us with a detailed background on errors for each of the models. We make use of that knowledge to address the possible start date for the onset of the dry spell. We tailor the superensemble to look for deficient spells of rains in a forecast string (of dates). The start date and duration are forecast from a string of values provided by the MMSE. Our studies addressed these forecasts for several examples of dry spells over recent years. The results were validated after the fact and it was noted that for both of the questions on the start date and the duration of the dry spell of the monsoon the MMSE performs better than the best model. The consistency of the superior forecasts from the superensemble makes it a viable product for real-time forecast operations. Our results were published in the journal Pure and Applied Geophysics (Pageoph).
